image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

items.synopsis: The number of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) cases have jumped close to 10 times higher in some states across Australia when compared to last year. Experts say COVID complacency and higher testing rates could be why.

title.children: RSV cases skyrocket across the country compared to same time last year

image.altText: A married couple wrap their arms around each other.

items.synopsis: More than five years after she is believed to have been murdered during a trip to Malaysia, Adelaide grandmother Annapuranee Jenkins is buried together with her husband Frank, who died last month without ever discovering what happened to his wife.

title.children: 'Together again': Grandmother at centre of Malaysian inquest laid to rest with husband

image.altText: A woman in a blue top in Adelaide's CBD.

items.synopsis: A bill is being introduced to South Australia's parliament that would make industrial manslaughter a criminal offence, after years of lobbying by one mother who lost her son in a workplace incident in 2004.

title.children: 'It burns you forever': A mother's near two-decade push for industrial manslaughter law reform after son's death

image.altText: A man in a checked shirt leans on a farm gate

items.synopsis: South East MP Nick McBride has left the Liberal Party, claiming "dark forces" in party factions created an environment of "disunity" and backstabbing.

title.children: South Australian MP quits Liberal Party over 'dark forces' and factionalism

image.altText: Thunderbirds players hug

items.synopsis: South Australia has secured the 2024 Super Netball League grand final hosting rights, two days before the Adelaide Thunderbirds take on the NSW Swifts in the decider.

title.children: 'Monumental' day as SA secures netball grand final hosting rights and stadium deal

image.altText: A cartoon advertisment in the australian financial review newspaper depicting Kate Chaney, her father and Thomas Mayo

items.synopsis: There has been bipartisan condemnation of a "racist" full-page newspaper ad campaigning against the Voice to Parliament, in which a female MP is depicted sitting on her father's knee while he hands money to an Aboriginal man below him.

title.children: No campaign's advertisement against Voice condemned as 'personal and racist attack'

image.altText: A black and white image of an older man with white hair holding a cigarette in his artist studio

items.synopsis: Post MeToo, audiences are reconsidering great artistic works in the light of their creators' transgressions. But is it truly possible to separate the art from the artist?

title.children: Picasso and Polanski committed horrific acts. What do we do with their art?

image.altText: A silver car with a dent and scrapped paint above its right front tyre park on the side of the road, another car parked behind

items.synopsis: As police in Adelaide's north were breath-testing one alleged drink driver last night, another crashed into the back of their car.

title.children: One alleged drink driver hits police car involved in breath-testing another

image.altText: A woman wearing a green ambulance uniform and a helmet climbing up a rock cliff.

items.synopsis: This paramedic knows exactly how valuable a voluntary ambulance service is in regional Australia. One of them helped her enter the world.

title.children: Taylor was born on the side of the road in regional SA. Now she is leading the volunteers who helped her

image.altText: A shiny new padlock hangs from a rusty old chain looped around a gate.

items.synopsis: A University of New England survey — the first of its kind in more than 20 years — will investigate the extent of farm crime across the country.

title.children: New national survey to shine light on hidden issue of farm crime

image.altText: A council building.

items.synopsis: Residents owing thousands of dollars to the Naracoorte Lucindale Council are given 30 days to start a payment plan or face their homes being sold at auction.

title.children: Home owners with unpaid rates risk losing properties as council goes after $110,000 debt

image.altText: A picture of a vineyard with a closeup of red wine grapes which haven't been harvested and have dried out on the vine.

items.synopsis: South Australian wine grape growers are switching crops or walking away amid the global red wine oversupply as key local stakeholders call for more support.

title.children: Australia's largest wine grape growing region diversifies to deal with one of the hardest years yet

image.altText: A lady with a gold wig and black sequin dress swings her arms dancing the nutbush.

items.synopsis: Almost 6,000 people didn't just break the world record, they blew it away in a colourful, spirited, boot-scooting celebration of the late queen of rock and 50 years of Nutbush City Limits.

title.children: Oh, Nutbush! Thousands stomp to world record as spirit of Tina Turner rocks Birdsville's Big Red Bash

image.altText: A woman wearing a camel jacket and black top leans on a fence surrounded by white roses.

items.synopsis: Jacqueline Bradley has worked all her life but found herself unemployed at 61. She's applied for dozens of suitable jobs but says the constant rejection makes it difficult to keep going.

title.children: At 61, Jacqueline can't find work. She doesn't eat until midday

image.altText: woman taking a selfie in a car

items.synopsis: Ahmad Hodroj is accused of murdering his estranged wife Amira Moughnieh after she died at a home in Sydney's south last night.

title.children: 'Loved life': Sydney mother of three allegedly murdered by estranged husband

image.altText: A PHEV on display at a Shanghai auto exhibition in 2023

items.synopsis: The latest sales figures suggest the age of the plug-in hybrid electric vehicle that can charge from a power point and fill up at the service station appears to be drawing to an end, at least in Australia.

title.children: Plug-in hybrids are being left in the dust as battery EV sales surge ahead

image.altText: Man's hands holds a handful of rusted metal coins, bracelets, watch, ring, under a blue sky, green trees, beach in distance.

items.synopsis: Memphis, who lives with autism, gets upset when other kids "see that he is different". Now his dad, Jason Marshall, has introduced him to a new pastime, "popular in Europe".

title.children: What is magnet fishing? Treasure hunters say it's an activity that's taking off especially for kids

image.altText: Natalie Baini

items.synopsis: Former Liberal staff Natalie Baini takes aim at the NSW division's treatment of women whilst the party's lawyer says her arguments are "legally embarrassing".

title.children: Ex-Liberal staffer tells court women should 'beware' party that doesn't respect women

image.altText: A dog with his tongue hanging out, lying on a lawn.

items.synopsis: A Gold Coast dad says his sons are beside themselves as a result of the "disgusting" crime. The family's car was also stolen and their house was trashed.

title.children: Heartless thieves steal blind dog, shove baby photos into toilet during daylight robbery

image.altText: A protester is challenged by security on tennis court.

items.synopsis: Australia's Daria Saville sees her Wimbledon first-round match interrupted by protesters who invade Court 18 before being arrested by London police, with the UK home secretary promising harsh punishments.

title.children: Dark day for Australians as climate protesters arrested at Wimbledon

image.altText: A man wearing a hat and singlet sits in a car taking a selfie on his phone

items.synopsis: A man facing 18 domestic violence charges after his former partner was found dead is granted bail as "the elephant in the room" of a potential murder charge is yet to be determined, a court hears.

title.children: 'The elephant in the room': Sydney man facing 18 DV charges granted bail after death of ex-partner

image.altText: A woman wearing a black and green jumper and glasses with her young daughter peering over her right shoulder by a window.

items.synopsis: Data from CoreLogic shows rental prices have continued to climb as the market battles chronic housing shortages and rising demand for housing. But despite an increase in the rental vacancy rate, rents are expected to keep rising.

title.children: 'I don't go to the doctor anymore': Angela rents in the most affordable capital city, but one more increase will make her homeless

image.altText: A soldier in protective camouflage gear ducks and holds his helmet as a mortar explodes into the sky behind him

items.synopsis: The counteroffensive is making steady gains, but Ukraine isn't taking any chances. While soldiers grind on in bloody battle, everyday civilians are preparing to defend their villages from a potential Russian advance.

title.children: While Putin was mired in personal drama, Ukraine was quietly carrying out its counteroffensive

image.altText: A Chinese woman with long hair smiling and gesturing in geometric black and silver dress on red carpet.

items.synopsis: The Hong Kong-born star had been suffering from depression for several years, her sisters said, with her condition deteriorating drastically over the last few months.

title.children: Pop singer CoCo Lee, who voiced Disney's Mulan, dies at 48

image.altText: Paul Smith in his 20s on a motorbike

items.synopsis: Lightning strikes in a split second. Those who survive being struck can be left with lifelong consequences, including cognitive disability, relationship breakdowns and a dark shadow over their mental health.

title.children: Paul was struck by lightning in his 20s. He was never the same again

image.altText: A woolly Merino ram with horns.

items.synopsis: The luxury fibre has fallen out of favour amid a global slowdown, with some producers choosing to dump lower-grade fleece instead of paying to store it.

title.children: Wool dumped in landfill as cost of living drives demand and price down

image.altText: Rocket launches on pad, beside two towers

items.synopsis: The Ariane 5 launcher embarks on its 117th and final mission, leaving Europe without a functioning space launch capacity for the first time since 1979.

title.children: Europe without dedicated space launcher after rocket takes off for the last time

image.altText: Green background and yellow text that reads The Nationals for Regional NSW.

items.synopsis: The NSW Nationals asked for and received $20,000 from its youth wing to spend on negative campaign ads in target seats in the recent 2023 state election, according to internal party documents.

title.children: Young Nats tapped for negative ad war chest in state election campaign

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading lower, defying gains on all three Wall Street indices overnight, while the Federal Reserve says interest rates will remain higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: ASX slides as Magellan Financial and miners tumble, Federal Reserve says high interest rates here to stay

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX finished 1.24% lower for the day, down to 7,163 points. All sectors finished in the red, with the exception of industrials, which gained 0.9% during trade. Basic materials was the worst performing sector, losing 1.7% overall, while consumer cyclicals dipped by 1.7% and financials fell by 1.5%. Looking at listed companies, there were some positive performances for the day: Block Inc +3.9% Webjet +1.7% Boral +1.3% WiseTech Global +1% Atlas Arteria +1% As for the bottom five worst performers: Star Entertainment Group -8.7% Magellan Financial -8.3% Lifestyle Communities -7.5% Polynovo -5.8% Syrah Resources -4.8% That's it for the blog today, thanks for sticking with us. We'll be back again tomorrow to cover the final day of trade for the week, along with the latest business news as it happens. See you then!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls to lowest level in more than a week

children.content: The ASX finished 1.24% lower for the day, down to 7,163 points.
All sectors finished in the red, with the exception of industrials, which gained 0.9% during trade.
Basic materials was the worst performing sector, losing 1.7% overall, while consumer cyclicals dipped by 1.7% and financials fell by 1.5%.
Looking at listed companies, there were some positive performances for the day:
Block Inc +3.9%
Webjet +1.7%
Boral +1.3%
WiseTech Global +1%
Atlas Arteria +1%
As for the bottom five worst performers:
Star Entertainment Group -8.7%
Magellan Financial -8.3%
Lifestyle Communities -7.5%
Polynovo -5.8%
Syrah Resources -4.8%
That's it for the blog today, thanks for sticking with us. We'll be back again tomorrow to cover the final day of trade for the week, along with the latest business news as it happens.
See you then!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're rapidly approaching the end of the trading day, but it's been a sea of red this afternoon for key stocks. As of 3:30pm, all of the big four banks have lost ground: ANZ -2% Commonwealth Bank -1.1% NAB -1.9% Westpac -1.5% The materials sector is also heavily in negative territory, led by major losses from iron ore producers. BHP -2.5% Rio Tinto -1.9% Fortescue Metals -1.5% Lynas Rare Earth -2.9% Star Entertainment Group has also suffered one of the biggest losses on the markets today — it's shed 7.6%. But Magellan Financial remains on track to be the worst performer of the day, having dropped by 8.2%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Big four banks and major miners in the red as ASX hurtles to finish line

children.content: We're rapidly approaching the end of the trading day, but it's been a sea of red this afternoon for key stocks.
As of 3:30pm, all of the big four banks have lost ground:
ANZ -2%
Commonwealth Bank -1.1%
Westpac -1.5%
The materials sector is also heavily in negative territory, led by major losses from iron ore producers.
Rio Tinto -1.9%
Fortescue Metals -1.5%
Lynas Rare Earth -2.9%
Star Entertainment Group has also suffered one of the biggest losses on the markets today — it's shed 7.6%.
But Magellan Financial remains on track to be the worst performer of the day, having dropped by 8.2%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good afternoon from me — I'm taking you through the rest of the trading day. First, a quick note: We've been so engrossed in monetary policy this week that we got ahead of ourselves on the blog and said we'd get more information about the RBA's rate pause. That was meant to be a reference to the US Federal Reserve, which released their meeting minutes overnight when they put rates on hold in June. We've since corrected it — but thanks to those eagle eyed readers for letting us know. The crux of those minutes from the June meeting of the Fed showed that the central bank was united in its decision to leave interest rates on hold. The minutes noted that although "some participants" wanted the Fed to proceed with its rate hiking cycle because inflation was taking too long to cool off, "almost all participants" found it was "appropriate or acceptable" to keep the rate between 5-5.25%. "Most of those participants observed that leaving the target range unchanged at this meeting would allow them more time to assess the economy's progress," the minutes said. "Most participants observed that uncertainty about the outlook for the economy and inflation remained elevated and that additional information would be valuable for considering the appropriate stance of monetary policy ." (Interesting to note that this is a very similar statement to what we heard from the RBA this week.) The minutes also reaffirmed the Fed's position that interest rates in the US will remain higher for longer, and still see a "mild recession" later this year — although there is still a slight chance they could avoid the downturn.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed Reserve meeting minutes show 'almost all' were in favour of June interest rate pause

children.content: Good afternoon from me — I'm taking you through the rest of the trading day.
First, a quick note: We've been so engrossed in monetary policy this week that we got ahead of ourselves on the blog and said we'd get more information about the RBA's rate pause.
That was meant to be a reference to the US Federal Reserve, which released their meeting minutes overnight when they put rates on hold in June.
We've since corrected it — but thanks to those eagle eyed readers for letting us know.
The crux of those minutes from the June meeting of the Fed showed that the
central bank was united in its decision to leave interest rates on hold

The minutes noted that although "some participants" wanted the Fed to proceed with its rate hiking cycle because inflation was taking too long to cool off, "almost all participants" found it was "appropriate or acceptable" to keep the rate between 5-5.25%.
"Most of those participants observed that leaving the target range unchanged at this meeting would allow them more time to assess the economy's progress," the minutes said.
"Most participants observed that uncertainty about the outlook for the economy and inflation remained elevated and that
additional information would be valuable for considering the appropriate stance of monetary policy
(Interesting to note that this is a very similar statement to what we heard from the RBA this week.)

The minutes also reaffirmed the Fed's position that interest rates in the US will remain higher for longer, and still see a "mild recession" later this year — although there is still a slight chance they could avoid the downturn.

image.altText: AFL logo

items.synopsis: The AFL is investigating the illegal distribution of explicit images of AFL players that have been shared online without their consent.

title.children: 'Appalling and disgusting act': AFLPA hits out at distribution of explicit player images

image.altText: The crowd cheers on a hill by the side of the road as an Australian cyclist raises his arms riding over the line to win a stage.

items.synopsis: Jai Hindley did his homework ahead of the Tour de France, and it pays off with an opportunistic breakaway on day one in the Pyrenees — now the Perth rider is living his cycling dream with his parents there to witness it, writes Sophie Smith.

title.children: 'Living like a monk' pays off for Aussie Jai Hindley, as his perfect Tour prep is capped by mountain breakaway

image.altText: UFC fighter Robert Whittaker speaks into the UFC microphone after a fight.

items.synopsis: Former UFC middleweight champion Robert Whittaker is fighting Dricus Du Plessis because he's there. But a win over the South African at UFC 290 can give him what he needs.

title.children: Robert Whittaker is fighting for a ticket out of purgatory at UFC 290

image.altText: Pat Cummins and Alex Carey celebrate as Bairstow looks at his stumps

items.synopsis: Australia captain Pat Cummins laughs off suggestions he should have withdrawn the controversial appeal for Jonny Bairstow's wicket in the second Ashes Test, and says he has no regrets — but admits he might change his mind in time.

title.children: Pat Cummins has no regrets over Jonny Bairstow stumping — but 'maybe down the track'

image.altText: A group of excited English women cricketers high-five and celebrate as a dejected Australian batter stands in the background.

items.synopsis: Australia's women are beaten in a cricket international for the first time since September 2021, as England keep the Women's Ashes alive with a narrow T20I win at The Oval.

title.children: Women's Ashes series alive as England ends Australian winning streak in T20I at The Oval

image.altText: A composite picture of two women sitting with contemplative expressions.

items.synopsis: A Noongar elder and advocates from both sides of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament debate fear many Australians will vote in the looming referendum without knowing what they are voting for.

title.children: These advocates are voting differently on the Voice — they want you to know why
